be combined with carbon and transported as a synthetic hydrocarbons
as well as be transported via liquid organic hydrogen carriers (LOHCs) or ammonia
. For synthetic hydrocarbons such as methane or methanol to be considered zero carbon,
used to produce them would need to come from the atmosphere either directly through DACCS
. LOHCs are organic substances in liquid or
states, which store hydrogen based on reversible catalytic hydrogenation and de

on 6.4.4), entailing the conversion of electricity to other energy carriers for subsequent use.

Moreover, ammonia is more easily condensable (liquefied at
s economically viable hydrogen storage and supply systems. Ammonia
production and transport are also established industrial processes (
, and hence ammonia is considered to be a scalable
carrier. At present, most ammonia is used in fertilizers (~80%), followed by many industrial processes,
such as the manufacturing of mining explosives and petrochemicals
hydrogen, ammonia can be used directly as a fuel without any phase change for internal combustion
. Ammonia can also be used in
low and high temperature fuel cells
, whereby both electricity and hydrogen can be
produced without any NOx emissions. Furthermore, ammonia provides the flexibility to be
use purposes. Ammonia is considered a carbon
generation, since in a complete combustion, only water and nitrogen are produced
n, ammonia could facilitate management of variable RES, due to its
scale energy storage capabilities. In this regard, production of ammonia via hydrogen
carbon generation technologies along with ammonia energy recovery
could play a major role in forming a hydrogen and/or ammon
decarbonization. However, there are serious concerns regarding the ability to safely use ammonia for
all these purposes, given its toxicity
whereas hydrogen is not considered toxic.
require new devices and techniques to facilitate their
scale use. Relatively high capital costs and large electricity requirements are also challenges for
technologies that produce hydrogen energy carriers. Yet, these energy carriers could become
economically viable through the availability of low
cost electricity generation and excess of renewable
A key challenge in use of ammonia is related to significant
, which is released from nitrogen and oxygen combustion, and unburned
ammonia. Both have substantial air pollution risks, which can result in lung and other injuries, and can
. Due to the low flammability of hydrogen energy carriers such as liquified
and ammonia (Li et al. 2018), a stable combustion
in the existing gas turbines is not currently feasible. In recent
developments, however, the proportion of hydrogen in gas turbines has been successfully increased,
elopment of gas turbines may enable them to operate on 100% hydrogen by 2030
